prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for resenting that my children see their mom as a hero?
My ex wife is a perennial fuck up. She’s been to jail on numerous occasions, had several affairs, lost more jobs than I’ve ever had, and currently lives with her mother. I was a single dad for three years to three children, years where I learned to braid hair so I could care for my daughter. I’ve remarried, and my wife and I provide the children with everything. We pay for their healthcare. We help them with their school work. We sign them up for activities they are interested in and take them to those activities. We pay for those activities. We help them with their school projects. My son is almost 16, and we will buy his car. My eight year old daughter needs braces, and we will pay for them. I ask their mother for no child support because she can’t even support herself. I don’t wish to hurt her. In fact, I’ve forgiven her for who she is and what she’s done. 
Fast forward to tonight: my daughter is entering a pageant. We’ve paid for the dress. We’ve paid the entrance fee. She gets me ask her questions she might be asked at the pageant. One was, “Who is your hero and why?” 
My daughter says, “Do you think I should say, ‘my mom?’”
I said, “ You realize you have family here? We provide for you. We registered you for this pageant. We attended the meeting. You live here full time. We care for you and love you. I know that you get to go to your mom’s every other weekend, and you have no chores there. You eat whatever you like (mom has food stamps), but it’s easy to be a parent two weekends a month. It’s harder to be a parent all the time.” 

I’ve never derogated their mother. I don’t want to cripple their image of her, but it’s frustrating as hell that they see her as this angel and don’t appreciate everything their stepmother and I do for them. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking if the person who wrote the situation is in the wrong. The scenario involves a father who's a single parent for three years, now remarried, and taking care of his kids. His ex-wife has a history of issues like jail time, affairs, job losses, and currently lives with her mom. He doesn't ask for child support because she can't support herself, and he's forgiven her.

The conflict comes up when his daughter is asked about her hero for a pageant. The daughter considers choosing her mom. The father responds by pointing out that he and his wife provide for the kids, while the ex only sees them every other weekend with no chores and uses food stamps. He's frustrated that the kids see their mom as a hero without recognizing their stepmom and him.

First, I need to assess if the father overstepped. He didn't directly insult the ex, but he did highlight the ex's shortcomings compared to his own. He's trying to make the daughter aware of the reality, but maybe in a way that's undermining the daughter's feelings. The daughter might feel torn between acknowledging her mom, who's still her parent, and the stepmom who supports her.

Legally, the father isn't obligated to ask for child support if the ex can't pay. But emotionally, the kids might still idealize their mom despite her issues. The father's frustration is valid because he's done a lot, but how he addressed it might not be the best approach. Telling the daughter that her mom is an angel without context could be seen as manipulating her perception. However, he didn't outright block the daughter from expressing her choice; he just expressed his feelings.

Is the father in the wrong? Well, he's not forcing the daughter to say one thing or another. He's sharing his perspective, which is reasonable. However, he might have been harsh in his explanation about the other parent's situation. But given the ex's history, maybe it's justifiable. The key is whether he violated any boundaries. Since he didn't attack the daughter for her feelings but explained his side, perhaps he's not in the wrong. The answer might be B (No), as he's advocating for his family's contributions without being abusive.
